text: <@UGV299K6H> the subset is excluding races with jumps in. I think you're right in that it's likely to be a nonsense result because I pulled it from the data after the fact. Even if this particular trigger doesn't work thanks everyone for the advice - it's all progress.

text: The way I see it that would offer a different starting point - I'd look again at races with lots of quite evenly matched runners, which will include races that aren't handicaps and exclude some that are. That would pull your analysis back towards looking at market dynamics. Obviously if it were some kind of fundamentals model that would be different.

elements.text: The way I see it that would offer a different starting point - I'd look again at races with lots of quite evenly matched runners, which will include races that aren't handicaps and exclude some that are. That would pull your analysis back towards looking at market dynamics. Obviously if it were some kind of fundamentals model that would be different.

text: If you said the same thing during the summer I'd point out that flat races are the main thing going on so they're bigger markets and suggest you check whether simple market size could be indicative, but if you're looking at recent markets then that's all weather racing and NHF, so I'd say it's not a great sign. In general; if your model is all about market behaviour it's probably safest to confine your analysis to market factors unless there's some plausible reason to expect a particular group of markets to behave in some particular way which you can then look for a way to verify.

text: I think initially I was wondering whether jump races were intrinsically different to flat. I'm sure they are in some ways, but I have no reason to believe that they differ in the particular way I am looking at. I think confining my analysis to market factors is great advice, cheers

elements.text: I think initially I was wondering whether jump races were intrinsically different to flat. I'm sure they are in some ways, but I have no reason to believe that they differ in the particular way I am looking at. I think confining my analysis to market factors is great advice, cheers

text: Flat and Jumps races are very different in running for reasons you can understand but I'd want a lot of data before I believed that they were all that different in terms of pre-off betting behaviour as there's no obvious causal link. That said; I'm overwhelmingly an in-running player so I couldn't say for sure.
